ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I furthered my understanding of the Spanish language as well as of Spanish culture and learned about some interesting and informative moments in the histories of certain Latin American countries.
Profeciency in intermediate level conversational spanich, more vocab, reading and comprehension skills, speaking skills
I learned how to better my grammar and conversational Spanish throughout this course.

I had mixed feelings about this class because I didn't actually learn any new content - it was all just review of content learned in L1 and L2. That being said what I learned was put into practice, through analysis of stories, short films, and a book at the end of the semester. However, I think the class could have been better organized so I learned more.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: well taught, integrates interesting media with content 
Weaknesses: there's a lot of assignments and it was often very confusing what we were supposed to do and which assignments to disregard because we deviated from the syllabus without warning.  Reymundi is very kind and thoughtful, but pretty confusing in her expectations.

strength- spoke a LOT
weakness- some worksheets felt pointless
The professors are great but there is a massive disconnect between the course directors plan for the course in the syllabus and what actually happens in the course.
The content of this course is engaging and conducive to learning.

The professor was really kind and the stories and movies we watched were interesting... but I didn't like how the class was structured AT ALL. We occasionally got lectures from the professor about content (all review from what we learned in past semesters), but other than that just filled out worksheets with partners. It wasn't that engaging and I didn't learn very much. Past semesters were a lot more interactive, with more full group discussions, projects, interactive activities, and so on. I rarely felt bored or disengaged, while this semester each class didn't feel very fruitful. I liked the court case at the end of the semester, that was fun, but each class was overall not too exciting, engaging, or educational.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: The course is obviously a lot of work, but that's the nature of language courses. In terms of recommendations, I would focus more on the process of professor selection and tell the student that Professor Reymundi is a very relaxed, sweet professor but that at times the class could feel disorganized and it could be difficult to know what we needed to do or how we were doing more generally (given the lack of consistent feedback on the work we turn in). That being said, again, Professor Reymundi is more relaxed than the other Spanish profs I've had, so I would recommend her to a student if that's what they are looking for and if they're willing to tolerate occasional frustration.
Yes. Spanish is a beautiful language
Yes. The class teaches you a lot and is not excessively challenging should you put in the work. Professor Reymundi is very willing to help and accommodate students.

I would say that it is a helpful course if you are just looking to strengthen the Spanish you already learned, or if you want to talk more about Spanish culture and art, but overall I wouldn't recommend it that much if you don't have to take it.
